The daily trials of a student is no stranger to the animé world; it's been constantly the focus of many titles that have gone by. Whether extracurricular activities (like a certain light music club) or high school crushes (like a certain girl with delinquent tendencies)--almost the entire spectrum of student life has been animated in one way or another. Yes, even the worries of a student approaching graduation has been in constant focus; the protagonist always searches for himself, wondering what he should do for the future after he leaves his high school. What should he aspire for? Will he succeed? Is it the rightdecision? The student spends the majority of the storyline wondering what he should become. Yet, sometimes, even this simplest of questions becomes the hardest to answer.


How do you think of what you want to become, when it seems that there's always someone out there who's leagues ahead of you? How will you stand out when you're surrounded by people who are already at the top? How do you get a chance at the spotlight when you're covered by the towering shadows of the people around you?


These questions are the concern of the main protagonist, Kanda Sorata, in this light novel-based animé entitled Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo, or The Pet Girl of Sakurasou. The first volume was published in 2010 as a work by writer Kamoshida Hajime, with the help of Mizoguchi Keji as illustrator. As of October 2012, 10 volumes have been released; the animé series based on the light novel series started on this same month.


Story: 10/10


The story is centered around the Sakura Dormitory (the namesake of the title), a student dormitory of the Suimei University for the Arts Affiliated High School. The dormers in this particular place are of the rather odd kind, being troublemakers and whatnot. However, making trouble is not the only thing they're good at; the dormers are known for their exceptional talent in their respective chosen fields. Animator, scriptwriter, programmer--the dormitory is home to students who can be called geniuses in their fields.


...well, except for one at least. This is the dilemma of Sorata. He can't seem to find his niché, especially now that he's (quite literally) surrounded by prodigies. He's not even supposed to be having this problem; he just ended up in the Sakura Dormitory after refusing to let go of a stray cat he found in exchange for his stay in the regular dorms.


The "pet girl" in the title refers to the newcomer, Shiina Mashiro. Being a new transferee in the Arts division of the school, she stays in the Sakura Dormitory out of recommendation of her cousin, who works as a teacher in the school and is also a dormer. Sorata ends up taking care of her, though, because the girl is the airhead that towers over all other airheads; it's almost as if she can't take care of herself. Thus, the "pet girl of Sakurasou."


The story is assembled just like any other romcom, with the overly dramatic first meeting and the artistic wind effects that come with it. Hidden beyond this, though, is a surprisingly deep story about how one normal guy finds his aspirations and dreams while living alongside prodigies that seem to be the best at what they do. His co-dormers don't step on his dreams, and they're certainly friends with each other, but he can't seem to take his first step towards his dream when his friends seem to have set the first step a bit too high for him to climb.


While maintaining the consistency of romance and comedy in each episode, the story does not fail to remind the viewers of the main protagonist's dilemma. Each scene reminds the viewers about how hard it is to get your momentum towards that one thing that you can call your mastery, when everyone else seem to be masters already. It hurts each time you fail and they succeed, and sometimes you just wish that they'd fail too, just so that they'd know what you're feeling. The constant pressure hurts, too; you feel like you need to be so much more than what you already are, since your peers seem to be doing the same thing. And it hurts even more when you notice that you're trying so hard just to attain so little, and yet they manage to do so much more without so much as breaking a sweat.


Don't let this theme steer you away, though. While this show has drama on all the areas where it needs it, the rest is covered by over-the-top reactions and hilarious situations. The show has watermelon paths, cat-based mechas, pantie horoscopes, players, messy hair, and... kickboards to the face. There's also the pantyshots, the see-through shirts, the fanservice, and the slightly lewd references that are a mainstay of romcoms. Comedy certainly doesn't lack in this show.


And where both comedy and drama is absent, romance is present. The broad spectrum of characters comes with the various love interests that seem to cling on to some nobody with nothing special about him. This show shuffles situations between girls, and each episode devoted to a girl develops both her and the main protagonist as a pair. Heck, you can find the pairing you'll root for by the end of episode 1 alone. The tears, the hugs, the blushes--romance certainly doesn't lack either.


In short, while romance and comedy is certainly a driving force in this show, what really got me hooked was the underlying question that's always on Sorata's mind. While something you won't usually encounter in a romcom, the show managed to blend both drama and romcom into a show that works so well you can cry twice in one episode, with two completely different reasons. You don't even know anymore if you're crying because you can relate to the protagonist, or it's simply leftover tears from some extremely hilarious scene a few minutes before.


Art: 8/10


If you're going to base an animé around an arts-oriented high school, you're gonna have to step your artwork up a notch. This show delivers this well, showing images of artworks that look professional. (Heck, chances are they were made by professionals anyway.) One scene in particular stand out for me, though. The characters were shown a painting of the deep, blue sea, and suddenly the scene shifts them to some surreal underwater world--as if they dived right into the painting. Putting it simply, it was one of the most beautiful scenes I've ever seen.


The rest of the scenes don't fail, either. When it's about comedy, we get over-the-top reactions, exaggerated faces and expressions, and bright, poppy colors. Shift to romance, and we get the red-pink overall tones, the sakura leaves flying along the breeze, the blushes on the character's cheeks, and all that should be there. If it goes to drama, we get the slightly darker colors and the backgrounds required to do some soliloquy or whatnot on part of the character.


Character designs are simple and clean, too--pretty much the way I like it. Nothing too complicated to look at, and certainly nothing unnoticeable.


Sound: 8/10


To be honest, I don't really just stop to listen to the show's background music, but I haven't felt that the music doesn't fit some particular scene, so it should be fine. It's worth noting, though, that the opening and ending themes are quite entertaining to listen to. Frankly, it's hard to skip them.


Character: 10/10


Here's the second shining part of Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo. Being a dormitory that's home to odd geniuses, the character roster is far from boring. We get a hyperactive animator, a scriptwriter who's a part-time player, a hikikomori programmer, and an airhead mangaka. Even the main protagonist, who's a self-proclaimed nobody, isn't as substandard as he thinks he is. They're both simple and fun to watch. Their interactions won't bore you, I can assure that.


However, character development is where they shine. Character interactions reveal other issues that would otherwise remain hidden to both the characters and the viewers. Hidden love interests, angst, envy--pretty much the sort of things you'd expect in a romcom like this. However, alongside emotions you'd feel in situations involving love, there's also those feelings you'd get when surrounded be people who succeed--loss of self-confidence, envy, and sometimes outright annoyance and hatred. The show reveals what people usually keep hidden inside themselves, and that's where the show is good at.


Enjoyment: 10/10


If it wasn't obvious to you before, I should probably say it now: Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo is well on its way to becoming one of my most beloved shows. Pretty much all that I look for in an animé is here, and they managed to make it work for once. I sympathize, I laugh (real hard), I get all fuzzy inside, and I sympathize all over again. It's a unique formula that I think makes this show one of the best out there.


Overall: 9/10 (Great)


All in all, Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo is a blast to watch. Best part is, it's only halfway through. As far as the 12 episodes go, I like this show so much I placed it on my Favorites list already. It's funny, it's beautiful, and it's heartwarming. I felt the issues directly, because I pretty much live in the same situation. (Just without the "pet girl" part.) I can only stress how beautiful the story is so far, but I'll have to wait 'till the ending to give it my final rating. For now, I'll be watching. And so should you.

The synopsis doesn't do this series justice. You heard me, a lot of us decide on whether to watch a show or not based on the synopsis, so I thought I'd just give a heads up. 
In describing this series with a single word, I'm going with "refreshing". The series is another one of those pseudo-romance shows where it does have bits and pieces of romance here and there but it isn't really the center of it all, well as far as it's 24 episodes spanned that is. This show is more about realistic drama and "actual" funny comedy. Realistic you ask? It's realistic becauseit's relatable and it's not over-the-top melodramatic shit.  By actual, I mean no boob humor and cliches.


The characters are awesome and they feel connectable and humane. They aren't stale like all the other standard MCs. Another bonus is that it isn't really just about the MC and his girl, the cast really feel like a cast where-in they all play a part and add in something to the story. I'm sure we're all sick and tired of side characters created for the sole purpose of fan service and comic relief by now, so have no fear because the ensemble that makes up this one is far from that.


The art and animation are awesome. Very modern, crisp, vividly colorful and fluid. Not much to say about that. As far as enjoyment goes, I was hooked from the very first episode and finished the whole series within a day. I'm sure you all know what that means. *wink* I rated this a 9 because honestly, my only complaint with this show is the fact that I wanted to delve in deeper into the "romance" part of Mashiro and Kanda's relationship. :3

Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo is for me a masterpiece anime.
Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo is a diamond in the rough give it’s a slice of life romance anime, but it goes so far beyond what one would expect from it, even if at the start it seems generic. 
I said it will be one of my favorite anime just after 3 episodes for personal reasons and I wasn't wrong as it was indeed a wild ride.
The story in Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo is one of failure in so many aspects of life, it’s about the hard work you put into your dreams, it’sabout friendships that go beyond everything I have seen this far in any anime and or tv series and in the end it’s a story about love and what this rare thing can do to us.


Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo does a few things almost to perfection in my opinion. The comedic parts are also hilarious at times …those puns ….just epic.


First the relationship between the main characters, I dare say it almost reaches perfection during the graduation speech, I have never cried so hard at any speech before. There are no words to describe the feelings that this anime invoked in me during the graduation speech.


The second thing it does so well is to make you really feel for each character (may it be their successes or failures) and there are few anime that did that for me (Clannad Afterstory is one anime that could invoke something similar form me)


And the third thing they did really well is the “romance” and love part. Given the only ones that mattered were the Misaki/Jin couple and the love triangle between Aoyama Shiina and Sorata though the others did add some interesting flavors to the anime as a whole. Why I think they did a really good job with this other than the Misaki/Jin couple (man that ending to it …just perfect I think very few people could be that dedicated and serious about their relationship at that age…) is the love triangle .


The love triangle, I will have to admit that up until the end confession I couldn't decide who Sorata would chose because it was just an impossible choice…..literary impossible and I think that this is something insanely hard to pull off as both Shiina and Aoyama had some impressive and interesting character developments….specially Aoyama :’(

By reading this synopsis of this anime you might not be inclined to watching this anime but that will be a big mistake because you're missing out. I'm not going to lie I didn't even know about this anime whatsoever and the only reason I even decided to watch it was because my favorite voice actor Takahiro Sakurai is in it as a main character named Mitaka Jin. 
But boy was I in for a surprise. I never expected an anime to be so well written and so freaking real. From the very beginning you are shown characters who are all in some way orform "strange"  or what people call them "wierdos".  However, each character especially Kanda Sorata the true protagonist of the anime all grow and develop in a way that people in reality can relate to. What I truly love about this anime is the fact that the anime does not just glorify all the good things that happen but also the harsh reality of the world. The characters go through pretty rough patches that essentially put all of them in a spot where they have to change. That is something not a lot of animes show. Not many animes have it that every main character go through a major change. Another thing about these characters is that all of them are true friends and have each other's back true thick and thin. They literally are always there for each other. Plus all the relationships between characters are so dynamic because every character is vastly different. There is no one character that is like the other. Each character has its own special upbringing and special storyline that has some relatable aspect that to it.  For example people  understand what it feels like to be in an unrequited love like Misaki, a struggling artist like Aoyama. The thing about this anime is that the characters are all human and not in a sense that they're "not aliens" but more in the fact that they have faults. No human is perfect and that what makes this anime truly amazing because it shows how human the characters they are. Their faults, mistakes, personalities are all real and none of them are glorified in away that makes them not relatable. The relatableness of the characters allow you to feel like you're in the anime and that is something all great animes do, pull you in and this anime was no exception. 


What is awesome about this anime is that is actually plausible. This whole storyline can actually be something that can happen in reality. This is what makes the anime really feel relatable. It's because it feels real. The only thing I would change about this anime is it's genre. It isn't only a romance or comedy or drama it really falls under "Slice Of LIfe". Actually, in my opinion, this anime really should be top of the "Slice Of Life" anime category because it's just that good. 


Another good thing about this anime that I love about it is that it gives closure but also is still open for a new season. Not many animes know how to do that. Either an anime gives the potential for a new season or they just end it. Never have I seen an anime end so well but also kept me wanting more. I like that there was an ending but a potential for more as if to show that this story doesn't really have an ending. It's like saying "Hey this anime is over but look the characters still are developing". The characters do end up growing but by the end of the anime it shows that the characters still have room to improve and that they aren't perfect and they aren't fully developed. So yeah this ending was very well written because it shows that even though the anime ended doesn't mean the characters are done developing.


If you like animes that have relatable characters that go through major developments in a world much like actual reality then you'll love this anime. Even if you're not fan of Slice Of Life animes you should give this anime a shot because it truly will be worth your time.

Moving, endearing, cheerful, sad, funny, frustrating, angry and tearful.
I experienced all of these while watching 'Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo' and I believe that you will too.  If you're thinking that this is just your 'run o' the mill' children's comedy show, you'd be wrong.
The anime is primarily a school comedy with slice of life problems and occurrences as well as a small bit of romance thrown in on top. I really enjoyed the various facets of school life that each of the characters seem to represent. There is the sexy but lazy and nonchalant teacher, the crazy upperclassman, the playboy senior, the strictfriend that will remind you of the right thing to do, the friend that will occasionally give you exactly the kind of advice that you need to get on with you life (while never taking any advice given to them despite having problems just as big as anybody else') and the one person that you can't help but feel responsible for, so much so that you give up many of the things that a normal high-school student would normally get to do, but you never regret it in the end. All of these are represented in this anime, along with many more that it would take to long to describe.\n\n
In summary; by the time that you have finished watching this show, you will feel that it was not what you were expecting, you will have grown to love the characters, you will appreciate your time in school more, whether it is over or not, and lastly you will most definitely not feel that you have wasted your time in the slightest.\n\n
Now go on and enjoy 'Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo'

This review like series of paragraphs does contain minor spoilers as to certain couples and implies the endings of certain archs so gonna point that out now 
So Sakuraso was an anime that i at first at least had very high hopes for. This anime took a very good topic which i found to be not explored nearly enough and decided to make an anime about it. This topic was one very close to me in my personal life and it was that of inferiority complex. I find this to be a brilliant topic that needs exploration. Then in the first 4 episodes it doesjust that, it has the main character accept the fact that he wanted her to fail but then realize that in the end it was her hard work that allowed her to prevail and in reality he just has to keep working harder. Now that's fantastic i love that and then you realize, wait this anime has like 20 more episodes to go. And so we continue the story of how every character INCLUDING the main character keep on suffering this inferiority complex. Well not EVERY chacacters problem is inferiority complex but most of them are and really it just confuses me, why have the same thing over and over again like after he deals with it once why does the same thing keep happening it baffles me. Hell this even happens to Jin and Jin was the one who mentored him through it. Now the second kind of topic of this anime is overcoming defeat. This is handled even worse than before because it is the same cycle over and over and over and over IT NEVER ENDS they just keep on failing and i keep on asking myself will it ever be over but no in the end it just keeps going.

 I guess i should talk about the characters. Well not much to say here Mashiro is kinda a very boring character if i can even call her a character... shes like a dog without her own kind of story she is just there for everyone elses story and for all of them to feel inferior same with misaki she just server the purpose of having Jin feel inferior to her. There is a romancish plot with them which is kind of boring but it does give Misaki some character so i guess thats fine. Some other characters like Rita exist although she is just there to also feel inferior because we simply didnt have enough of that. Ryūnosuke is there i guesssss as a tsundere. Really i have no idea what his place is in the story and i find him to be very unnecassary and just there as a guy for a shoe horned in romance plot between him a Rita and also as a character to move the plot along since he gives Sorata the incentive to start his video game making project. Lastly we have Nanami who is there for the aforementioned topic of overcoming failure and really she just fails so much and she just keeps failing i mean my good lord Nanami and Sorata just fail so much in this anime and they just repeat the process of overcoming it over and over, i find it terribly boring and also at some point i felt like they could give these characters a break. I mean sure it is realistic that someone could fail that much but this is an anime after all and it's less that i feel bad and more that i feel that there is very little progression going on with that whole plot of them failing since there is never any success and so it ends up being repetitive and unnecessary.   

Now that we have the characters rounded up i can talk about the romance plots because i feel these deserve a special looking at as being separate from the main plots since they do not fit in with any main theme of the anime. But i will say it is a tad better than the romance between the leads because it does give Misaki more of a character since she clearly has problems she to cannot deal with. As well, on a side notel it seems very stupid that he would reject her for him not being good enough i dont know may be just me but if you love a girl and they love you back like what does not being a good writer have anything to do with anything ugh well whatever next we have Ryūnosuke and Rita. Next we have Nanami who is the other love intrest to Sorata. This goes nowhere


As well i don't really feel the need but i guess i should talk about the music and art. THe tracks are mostly fine with the opening being pretty stupidly catchy i didnt find any problems its your standard fair but i also didn't find anthing amazing. I dont find a need to comment on the art of an anime like this since it's art just has to present cutesy characters and cutesy scenes and it does that although it does get nice when they get to the serious scenes the art did actually surprise as to how good it was but other than that not much to say. 


In the end i enjoyed the first 4 episodes and then got bored watching the same thing over and over. Also there that whole thing about the building being torn down that had nothing to do with the main themes of the anime and I guess it was to show that umm errr their bonds are so fragile that by not living together they would stop being friends... i don't know it was just kinda put in there so that the anime could end. I heard a lot of good things about Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo, so I decided to try it out. I didn't know too much about it besides that it was sad at times with good comedy. I had high expectations for this anime, and i was not disappointed in the slightest except for the last episode which i'll get to later on in the review. Surprisingly the anime was much more dramatic than I expected and i hadn't seen much dramatic anime before, but overall I liked the dramatic feel to the show. I'll tell you why my expectations were met and/or exceeded inthe categories below.


Characters/Development: 10/10


The reason for me loving this anime so much was because of the characters at Sakurasou. I think why I enjoyed these characters so much wasn't because of their individual personalities because honestly their personalities who pretty cliche with the crazy-energetic girl, the shut-in, the quit innocent girl, the womanizer (at first), and the normal guy just goes to high school, but with all that said I extremely enjoyed the relationships between the characters. How everyone interacted with each other and cared for each other why quite outstanding. It was joyous and saddening to see what these characters went through TOGETHER and how they developed as characters TOGETHER. This is what makes this show great in my eyes. Just how the relationships all have an important and crucial meaning to the anime and helps with the overall enjoyment of the show. I really wish more shows had this kind of style with their characters. Also each character had a decent past/development time to get to know the characters even more and understand why they make the decisions they make. One of my favorite cast's ever along with Steins:Gate.


Story: 8/10


This was probably the weakest part for me about the series. But that doesn't mean it was lacking. It just seemed the story wasn't very clear to me. Basically things came up and the characters got involved into some activity and did whatever activity it was or some character had an issue to be solved and it was solved. I don't want to say too much more or else I will spoil everything. Do not worry too much about the story going into this, the characters are well enough to make up a good story and all intertwines together. In short though, Sorata (the male protagonist) doesn't know what he wants to do with his life, so he thinks of something and wants to work really hard as everyone else at Sakurasou and thrives off of their hard work to work hard by himself, all the while having to take care of Mashiro. 


Here's what bugged me about the story, I didn't like how the romance was played out. Without spoiling anything, the romance in the anime seems confusing and all out of the place and it made me disappointing because some characters weren't treated fair or payed any attention to when they should be. I may sound confusing right now, but if you should ever watch this all the way through, I think you'll understand what i'm trying to say.


Oh, there's a lot of feels and drama in this anime, which can be a good or bad thing. I personally liked all of it and I don't even like this kind of stuff. But I had the waterworks almost runnin at times. This anime is saddening but in a good way. You'll like it.


Art 10/10


I didn't have any complaints with the art or animation at all. It seemed very fluid and crisp to me at all times. Great choice of colors throughout the anime and the character designs were fantastic. Nothin much to say here. One should not be disappointed in this category. No scenes ever lacked any detail. They always put the most detail into every scene which I liked.


Sound 10/10


I looooooved the openings and ending in this series. Especially the first opening and ending. I could listen to them all day! The second opening was good as well and the second ending. They fit well with the series quite smoothly. The OST's were excellent as well. They played a "serious" song when things got serious and were completely appropriate for the times. They had "comedic" songs during comedic times. Basically, they played the right music at the right times to fight with the current scene.


Overall I enjoyed this anime so much due to its characters togetherness's development. It was great to watch what they went through in a good way and how they accomplished their tasks. Episode 23 was hands down one of the BEST EPISODES IN ANY ANIME I have ever seen. I LOVED this episode more than any other one and 22 was good too, but 23 was AWESOME. The emotions were running VERY high and I just loved how well-executed this episode was. During the middle of the series you might start to get bored, but trust me if you do, just wait it out. It only gets even better. I would say the enjoyment levels are high towards the beginning and end of the anime, not to say the middle wasn't enjoyable, it was, but not as much in my opinion. With all of that said, I enjoyed this anime thoroughly from start to finish.

It's about time I wrote a review for my favorite anime of all time! You hear that? Favorite anime. That means I like this anime more than any anime ever made! Calling me biased at this point is as much of an understatement as saying One Punch Man is overrated.
I love Sakurasou. It is one of my first ever anime series (definitely one of my first 15 series) and also the only 2 cours anime series that I finished in one day. So why do I love Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo? Is it because it's flipping hilarious? Or is it because the romantic tensionis literally out of this world? Is it because of the intense drama about the war between hard work and talent? Or is it because of the amazing character dynamics and development that other romcoms can't even hold a candle to. Obviously it's the combination of them all!


Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo hit my heart like a wrecking ball. Chasing your dreams has always been a heavily used theme in anime, but Sakurasou nails it so damn well. By the way guys, the theme of chasing your dreams is the main story. Sure, it's a romantic comedy, but the romance is nothing compared to the struggles of the characters trying to do what they do best, and even better. Did I mention characters? Of course, since Sakurasou has probably the most deep and well developed character cast of any romantic comedy ever made. There aren't just 2 main characters like most romcoms, there are 5! FIVE! That's 2.5x more characters, with 2.5x more character development. 


Ah, and of course, the great war between hard work and talent. Something that as a musician, I am extremely aware of. The hard working ones are always jealous of the talented ones. The talented ones are sometimes misunderstood. People dedicated to art find doing their craft incredibly easy, as well as finding everyday chores extremely hard. Sakurasou captures this boundary between the hard workers and the talented extremely well. It's like my life was unfolding in front of my eyes. 


Pros:

- One of the best cast of characters in romcom history.

- The amount of character development this show has, especially for its large cast, is unrivaled.

- Genuinely hilarious! It has slapstick comedy, amazing skits, great character interactions, as well as Mashiro! A recipe for laughs!

- Breathtaking art and character designs! The background art is lovely and the characters are full of energy!

- Great soundtrack as well!

- Beautiful depictions of its themes. It really highlights the differences between hard work and talent.

- Great depth and suspense during dramatic scenes.


Cons:

- Despite being a romcom, the romance is fairly lackluster.

- Some characters are fairly cliche. Sorata is pretty generic.

- A pretty hit or miss series, especially when it comes to the comedy and drama. 


Story: 10

It's a romcom, but the story really isn't about love. Well, the story is actually all about love, but not the romantic kind! Sakurasou is a story about your love for what you have, as well as your love for what you can have. It's about love for your friends, love for your dreams, love for your talents, and so much more. As stated before, the romantic aspect of this series is definitely its weakest link, but its weakness is overshadowed completely by how this show dives into love in general. Some people are talented! Those people must learn to love what they have and to never take it for granted. Some people aren't born with talent! They must learn to love what they want to do and work hard at it, and to chase your dreams until your legs give out. 


Sakurasou is a story about life. Life is full of struggles and hardships. Life is full of happiness and laughter. Different people live different lives, and that means you won't agree with each other all the time. That's a natural part of life, especially if you live with many others. Sakurasou jams different characters under one roof, and through the interactions that they have, teaches you that to live life to the fullest, you don't have to understand each other. You simply have to accept each other, and to carry on with each other.


And of course, Sakurasou is really about the war between work and talent. These are two ends of the spectrum that never understand each other, but Sakurasou shows that opposites complete each other. The two will always have qualms with each other, for that is natural. But that doesn't prohibit love from developing between the two.


Art: 10

Sakurasou, aka Porn For the Eyes, is incredible art wise. The background art is just simply breathtakingly gorgeous, especially that sakura tree scene in the beginning of the series. Just completely eye melting. The character designs are also very detailed and full of energy! Mashiro's design is absolutely adorable!


Sound: 9

The soundtrack for this show is also incredible! However, as good as the soundtrack is, it isn't anything particularly mind blowing. The OPs and EDs are very catchy. But in the end, let's be honest. Sakurasou isn't a show known for having a legendary soundtrack.

Voice acting? Now that's a different subject. The seiyuus nailed the characteristics of each character perfectly! Mashiro's introverted nature was captured especially beautifully, and added on to her endearing nature.


Character: 10

The main gem of this treasure trove, the characters of this show are what make this show stand out from other romcoms. With a much larger cast than other romcoms, one might expect this show to have less character development than other romcoms. Well, the thing is, this show surpasses other romcoms in terms of sheer character development. Each character is developed so much that they become full fledged protagonists. It really doesn't feel like a show with one protagonists, but a show with five! That just shows how amazingly well executed the relationship between the five friends are. While yes, the show does focus more on Sorata and Mashiro, it really gives every character a lot of love. Each character has their own dreams and ambitions. They have their own flaws and insecurities, and they are quick to become jealous of each other. However, even through massive misunderstandings and falling outs, this group of friends still manages to join together in the end to become the most united group of friends in anime.


Enjoyment: 10

Like I mentioned before, this was the only 2 cours show that I have ever managed to finish in one day! That's how drawn in I was to this show.


Overall: 10

It's my favorite. Sure, maybe its because it is one of my earliest anime series. But it's also because it hit me right in the kokoro. I am someone who knows the struggles of hard work vs. talent more than most people, which made this series incredibly impactful. I highly recommend this to someone who wants a romcom that dives much deeper than simple romance, as well as to those who have dreams and aspirations of their own to chase.


TL;DR: You ain't gonna watch it? I guess I'll have to resort to Plan C.

There are moments when watching a show where you feel entirely disconnected from some of the characters and you struggle to understand there actions and you question them. Sakurasou no Pet had these moments, but it made up for them with the complete variety in the characters. To script and weave the story to make you whole heartedly understand who these people were, made this for me, an outstanding and different show. All to often, shows are made with an aim to bring an audience in by making it look pretty and shiny and then the story lacks.
But Sakurasou no Pet felt like it hadsomething to say and by the end made itself clear. I do feel that the constant morale bashing of hard work put a bump in an otherwise straight road. (Possibly due to my own inability to work hard). On the other hand the themes of realism and what motivates people did fall in to place nicely. It has to be said that I feel the "Romantic" side, was at time forced and I can't help feeling it ignored certain characters; like Miyahara, who had more of a story to tell. I'm not sure how invested I was in  the romantic side because everybody and there mothers seemed to be in love. I honestly believe that they could have delved more into Miyahara's and Nanami's story, which when you look back on it makes you question her actions entirely and in terms of realism they could have left at least a couple of people alone. \n\n
But only a small part of the story is sacrificed to add this romantic side and the rest of it I truly enjoyed. Pet Girl of Sakurasou is a romantic comedy-drama focused on our male lead, Sorata, forced to take residence at a school dormitory of eccentric students skilled in different talents. Upon becoming part of Sakurasou, Sorata has to wind up caring for a female resident named Mashiro Shina who is a world-renowned artist having a completely ridiculous lack of common sense as such where she does not understand basic things such as dressing herself and appropriate social interaction.
Before I tackle what I did enjoy out of this, I might as well address my issues with the series. A good chunk of the comedy for this relieson the eccentric quirks of many of the Sakurasou residents to carry it along and these habits tend to either give one the impression that this baby will be typical fare for a rom-com or the traits in question border on obnoxious or absurd, notably Mashiro's ridiculous lack of common sense and Misaki's "genki gal" archetype. It also doesn't break any new ground for a rom-com as Sakurasou milks the typical character types and cliches of the genre, as well as the series usually getting overbearing with the drama it delivers with major developments in its run.


Still if you can endure the series long enough, you will come to see that Sakurasou has more to offer up with its story thanks to the problems facing its cast. Many of the residents at the dormitory are outcasts of the school despite their talents and each find themselves struggling to overcome their own personal ordeals as a result of whichever talent they have. Some of the residents are struggling to be successful at whatever medium they would like to be involved with, while others are talented as such where it is easy for them to get by while oblivious to how envious others may perceive them. These struggles are believable and relatable as there are points in life where one can find themselves frustrated with setbacks to their goals and may take their frustrations out on someone they know who would be more talented than them. Each resident, including Sorata over time, comes to rely on one another for emotional support in their struggles and even develop romantic interests throughout the show's run and said feelings are also genuine despite the show's occasional slipping into melodramatics.


While not groundbreaking in any way, Pet Girl of Sakurasou still carries some rather solid character exploration and chemistry in regards to the challenges of gaining fame and acceptance in spite of having an introduction that would have you assume it would be typical rom-com fare. It won't be everyone's cup of tea, but the series it least offers something to connect with beyond dabbling into the normal rom-com antics.

You know, the phrase "never judge a book by its cover" is something that is thrown around everywhere in all sorts of situations.  Ranging from describing people, to describing a show like this.  This review is on the wonderful anime known as "Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo", or in the english translation, "The pet girl of Sakurasou."
Story (9/10): The story of Sakurasou, as I will refer it to as henceforth, revolves around the life of our main protagonist Sorata.  Because of his obsession with saving cats from the streets, Sorata is deemed to be kicked out of the dorms of his prestigiousschool, and forced to live in a small dorm known as "the sakura dorm", a place where all the reject and strange students go to.  Until one day, the dorm manager of the sakura dorm tells him to go pick up her relative, which results in Sorata, meeting the lovely kuudere Mashiro, the newest member of the Sakura dorm.  Unable to take care of herself, Sorata is deemed on "Mashiro Duty", meaning, he has to take care of essentially all of her basic needs.  And well, hilarity ensues.  Regardless of the fact that I said "hilarity ensues", the story of Sakurasou is incredibly deep.  The main focus and the high point of the show, are its characters.  (I'll get onto that later.) The show itself has great pacing and can hook the watcher into the show with its drama and comedy.  However, I have to say that the way Sakurasou shines the most, is in its realism.  Even though the characters themselves don't face ordinary problems like most people do everyday, each of them is relatable in some way, and that just makes the show fantastic.  It's the pure fact that the characters can be portrayed as real people, that the show excels at doing so.


Characters (10/10): Rather then doing my normal spiel of naming off certain character names and describing their personalities and whatnot, I'm going to go a different route in summarizing them and explaining without heavy spoilers.  (Cause doing that WILL give huge spoilers away.)  As I have said before, the reason why this show is such a gem, is in its characters.  Each of them starts off as a basic one-liner cardboard cutout where they're only defined by that specific trait.  However, as the series goes on, each character is hit with certain problems that pertain to them, that change them drastically.  By the end of the series, they're almost completely unrecognizable from when they were from when they started.  The characters are also great because of the show's length.  With 24 episodes, the show has so much time to work with, using every bit of that timespan to give gradual changes that make the characters wonderful.  Another thing that makes the characters great are their bonds.  The main characters in this series are seriously tied together and as the series goes along, the way the characters grow together, is a gem in and of itself.  It was fantastic to see such great development as they all laughed and cried with each other.  The supporting cast isn't anything to shy away from either.  Though they barely play a role, they do a good job at interacting with the main characters, and helps progress the story further in their own special way.


Art and Sound (9/10 and 8/10): The art in this animation is very nice.  It uses a great palette of light colors and give it this nice and fluffy feel.  On the other hand, the palette can be used in its more dramatic scenes and give a fantastic contrast compared to the normal fluffy feel.  Although, I would be lying if I said I didn't like the actual paintings that was featured in the anime.  As for sound, the anime hosts 2 Op's and Ed's.  The first OP is probably my favorite track out of the 4.  It's sounds just so happy and fulfilling, that it just wants to make you smile.  Not to mention the scene in the OP where all the characters are covered with paint, great touch there.  The first ED is also good and gives a nice resolution feel with the anime.  As for many anime, the OP's and ED's are replaced with new tracks.  Which can or cannot turn someone to skip them.  For the second OP, I have to almost put it up with the first OP.  It sounds good, it does, but it sounds a bit more sad and less upbeat then the first OP did.  As for the second ED, I don't like it.  The first time I saw it, it just made me turn away from it.  In my opinion, it doesn't sound good.


Enjoyment (10/10): Ever since I watched Clannad:Afterstory, I could never find a good enough anime to fill the void it left me with.  Angel Beats! was good, but it wasn't able to do enough for me.  Until this show came along.  Sakurasou is definitely one of those shows that touched my heart.  Just to see the beauty of friends getting along, the trials and tribulations that they had to go through, the bonds that the characters achieved along the way, it was all nice to see.  Also, to see such change from the main character, I was just happy.  I think I cried a few times as well.  The story of this anime is very touching, and I would highly recommend this to pretty much anyone because of just how wonderful these characters are.  Although, one thing that bothered me a little bit, was the slight inconsistencies with the story telling.  It jumped from one person to another, and it seemed a bit random at times.  Another thing that bothers me is if I want a second season or not.  The thing is, the anime opens itself to a second season, but I feel as though the second season wouldn't be as great as the first.  There's also the matter of following the light novels, which according to what I heard, ends a bit weird, so I'm a bit skeptical.  On that note, I love Sakurasou.  There, I said it.  And you should to.

Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo is one of my favorite rom-coms. Unlike other stereotypical rom-coms, Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo does a great job with originality and enjoyability, it just made me want to keep watching.
Story [9/10]: The story of course is probably one of the most important aspects to a show and Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo does it right. For some reason they all just seem to be so geniune.


Enjoyment [10/10]: I enjoyed the hell of this show. I did not expect to fall in love with it that much but I did. I don't know what else to say but I loved it and I truly enjoyed watching each and every second of this show.

Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo (hereby referred as SPK) is probably one of the best slice of life anime of 2013.
I found SPK to be a very enjoyable anime that explores themes that much of the audience will be familiar with, especially if you're an adult. The characters in this story undergo trials and suffer depressing setbacks. Through these trials, characters achieve progression. Anyone who has been disappointed in life - whether it be rejection from a college or from someone you loved will relate to the story very well and begin to sympathize with them.
Like many anime (unfortunately), there are elements of ecchi andfan-service that can detract the story from its course. However, I found the story and characters to be COMPELLING - which in my opinion, makes it the best.


The production value of this anime is incredibly high. Big kudos to JC.Staff for delivering such a polished product. The soundtrack for SPK contains appropriate music for variety of situation the characters face in the anime. My personal favorite was Days of Dash piano arrangement. I believe this particular piece embodies the emotion of the story. The artwork also deserve high praises. The one particular scene with sakura tree was... indescribable. Oh my gosh. It's just pure beauty. It just captures your emotion.


There are many criticism directed at this anime - some of them fair, some of them undeserving. The biggest criticism of this anime (actually, the whole series) is that, it fails to deliver an appropriate resolution. This is in part due to fact that anime finished around vol. 7 of the light novel. There are 12 light novels (2 side stories), so it's understandable that they could not give a happy ending many of us are familiar with. My biggest pet peeve is talent vs hard-work theme that receives a dead-horse beating and sends a wrong message to the audience.


I still however, wholeheartedly recommend this anime; if the author of the series had better writing abilities, this series could have been the best slice of life since Toradora!


(Warning: DO NOT READ THE LIGHT NOVELS, and second season is in doubt due to poor merchandise sales and the fact that there are not enough materials in the new light novels to deliver a second season. OVA may be a possibility and second season could be a possibility if JC.Staff decides to diverge from the light novels)

The story of the Pet Girl of Sakurasou is, probably to your discontent, definitely an ordinary slice of life anime. The main character, Sorata Kanda, is kicked out of the normal dormitory at Suimei High School of the Arts for keeping a cat, and is forced to move into Sakurasou Hall, which is a congregation of the school’s most eccentric, trouble causing students. As he gets accustomed to the dorm, a world renowned painter who cannot care for herself, Mashiro Shiina, also moves in. The story progresses by illustrating the residents’ daily lives, romantic relationships, and hard work and talent. 
Pretty cliché and corny huh?Well let’s get straight to the point: it definitely is. There honestly is nothing too unique about much of the anime. But before you skip the rest of this review and vow to never watch this peculiar-sounding title that resembles tons of other shows in its genre, listen to what I have to say. What could such a genre of anime do that makes it totally stand out from the rest of the crowd? In my opinion, it can’t do too much that is different. The Pet Girl of Sakurasou may not stand out, but it excels at many aspects that are representative of a slice of life/romance show. Most significantly, it is extremely down to earth and relatable, and that is the true embodiment of the slice of life/romance genre. 


This will be one of my longer reviews, since it does take some effort to put an “ordinary” show in a good light, so please bear with me. 


Story: 

The main problem with the show, is what I have stated before: it is very cheesy at times. If you’ve played Pokemon, it’s kind of like listening the talks about the power of love and connection between Pokemon and trainer. A lot of the show focuses on a couple of themes and traditional slice of life stereotypes, that come up over and over again. The first half of the series demonstrates the typical Toradora style like qualities, where the characters are introduced and develop, and in general, is a lighthearted and humorous portion of the show. There is nothing you probably haven’t seen in the first half, and honestly, some portions of show just made me cringe from how hackneyed it was. 


The anime really started getting good when it reached, specifically, the Christmas episode, when the interactions in the first half began to turn into more serious drama. The hard work that they put in towards their goals that started in the first half was translated into authentic results, and romance begins to unfold. In the second half, the show becomes very realistic, especially focusing on hardships and how things don’t always turn out the way you expect them to. Although the same themes came up, they took a different approach to portraying it, by instead focusing on keeping it realistic by using a hint of unfortunate events, and it was done admirably. 


Characters: 

It is not unheard of that some characters do a complete 360 degrees on their original personality after experiencing an extremely traumatic event. While some people might call this good character “development,” when does this happen in real life? When you are getting close to adulthood, certain ideologies, emotions, and attitudes definitely shift, but much more likely, you stay true to yourself at the end of the day. 


Characters in The Pet Girl of Sakurasou experience all those changes, encounter hardships, and sometimes can’t help but to release their emotions. While some episodes did very little to advance the character’ personality traits, many of the crucial episodes did a good job of making you feel like you are in their shoes. The only problem I have is that some character's traits don't seem to explained very well, and some characters just have obliviousness that may make you annoyed. 


In my opinion, the cast is likeable, but some characters lacked very “outstanding” features. As it is a major character oriented show, understanding the character’s emotions and past experiences is a necessity for finding the show to be relatable. But with the wide variety of characters, I would say it is is difficult to find someone you cannot relate to. 


Soundtrack and Art: 

The soundtrack consists of mostly lighthearted, upbeat tracks, especially evident in the first half of the show. I did feel a lack of emotional tracks, evidently by how there was this one piano song that played constantly towards the last few episodes. The openings and endings were likeable, especially the second ending, which might be one of my favorite anime endings ever (it was actually the reason I found out about this anime, after hearing it on an anime station). Besides that personal favorite, I found that many tracks tend to be reused in similar situations, and not too much of the OST was memorable. 


The art heavily fitted the lighthearted nature of the show, and was quite accurate. Many of the paintings and drawings in the anime, you could tell, had a lot of detail and effort put into them to live up to Mashiro’s prodigy status. In an attempt to unite the art and soundtrack, the show did a lot of overlaying of the dialogue and theme songs, putting some scenes before, during, or after the theme songs. The transitions they had with these were very well done, and added very much needed variety. 


Beginning, Ending and Influence: 

The start of the anime was really something that probably turned a lot of users away. It instantly started off with fanservice, seemingly superficial humor, and the fact that the main character is stuck with a girl who doesn’t even know how to dress just screams pervertedness. The anime then continues to gives off vibes of sexual tension for quite a few episodes that makes it seem like a harem, fanservice-based anime that immediately gives off a feeling of shallowness. Not to mention the title sounds kind of…suggestive. During some parts of the anime, even towards the ending, it feels like it is trying too hard to make you care, when all it needs to do is just simply tell the story.


However, the anime more than redeems itself with its very down to earth nature and superb character development. Although it was never very addicting to me, the superb pacing and execution made every episode satisfying to complete. The ending of the anime is a very appropriate closing, leaving you to your own imagination and preference to what happens next, and can be emotional when you are very attached to the characters. 


The hard work ethic and courage that the characters embody are very applicable to reality, and thus, can definitely inspire others. No matter how corny that last sentence sounds, it doesn’t have to be if it is executed and portrayed properly, and that aspect is what The Pet Girl of Sakurasou excelled at.

High school rom-coms are a staple of anime these days, it seems we get at least three or four each new season. Granted, the target demographic of most anime is high school students, the rom-com is fairly safe genre (there are some tried-and-true plots and character archetypes that can at least guarantee modest success), and the fairly light demands on animation undoubtedly save money ( you can reuse the same backgrounds and the movements of the characters are usually simple). So from a production company's standpoint a show of this genre is a sound business decision, but in a genre this popular it can behard to stand out. Does 'Sakurasou' achieve this feat? (OK, you can see my overall score up in the corner so my opinion is probably not hard to guess).


'Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo' is licensed by Sentai Filmworks and can be legally streamed on Crunchroll.


-Story-


One life tip you might hear a lot is that multi-tasking is counterproductive, that trying to do too much can actually cause you to accomplish less overall. 'Sakurasou' is a series often compared to 'Toradora!' and the latter certainly tried to do too much. 'Sakurasou' went with a much simpler focus and ended up doing better overall. Not stellar, but still better. "Average guy finds himself in a situation where he is innocently living in close contact with a number of beautiful women- hilarity and fanservice ensues" wasn't new when Love Hina used it a decade ago, but premises are cheap anyway, so let's look at the execution.  The first half of the show is about as generic as it gets, mostly relying on creating situations where Sorata will encounter Mashiro in various states of undress, or Mashiro will say something loaded with sexual undertones without realizing it. The second half does improve, going for a more interconnected plot and having a distinct theme ("How do you handle being an average person in the presence of a genius- somebody who will probably always be better than you no matter how much effort you give?") and it even manages to create some emotional moments when various characters encounter adversity. Genre cliches still abound, and the final arc is pretty generic and without any kind of romantic conclusion (this show is adaptation of the only the first part of a series of novels) but points for having at least a few bites of substance.


-Art-


Pretty, with numerous bright warm colors. The palette looks like flavors from an ice cream shop (odd way of describing it, but that's the best way I can think of). The animation quality is fine and I don't really have much else to say.


-Sound-


Mostly light and happy J-Pop. I still listen to the first OP on YouTube from time to time, so points there. The OST is fine for the show, but nothing to write home about. The voice actors all seemed to fit, with Mashiro's abnormal personality coming through well.


-Characters-


Sorata is a thoroughly average, hapless nice guy- dime a dozen in this genre. He's there to be an Audience Surrogate and that's what he does. Then you have the mysterious girl in Mashiro, the romantic foil in Nanami (who did have the most interesting arc, being the most devoted to what she wanted to do but also encountering the most difficulty- I was definitely rooting for her by the end) the best friend who's far more outgoing, the teacher who doesn't act remotely responsible enough for the position of Community Leader, and a couple oddballs for comedic effect. Cut and dry standard fare. They have their moments of being entertaining, I won't say these are botched characters, but they're still playing close to the archetypes. The highlight of the cast is the computer genius recluse Ryuunosuke- I have a personal preference for snarky characters who are perfectly willing to ruthlessly cut through another character's BS right in their face and give them the cold hard truth regardless of how they feel about it. 


-Enjoyment-


I came to watch an enjoyable romantic comedy, I got an enjoyable romantic comedy. No complaints here.


-Overall-


Pretty animation and a little substance to plot save 'Sakurasou' from complete mediocrity, but generic characters and an inconclusive romantic ending keep it from being anything more than just a bit above average. I've waffled between giving it a 5 or a 6, so... 5.5

Our Lord Almighty "J.C Staff" has yet brought us another anime that will go down in my books as one of the best animes that they ever made along with Railgun, Toradora, Little Busters: Refrain, and probably Index II. Scratch that, screw Index

The Pet Girl of Sakurasou is a rom-com anime that focuses on a second year high school student named Sorata who lives in a dorm named Sakurasou, the dormitory for delinquent children at the school where Sorata goes to. One day, a dumb cute blonde girl named Mashiro who happens to be a greatpainter and artist moves into Sakurasou. 


The first half of the series was, honestly, not that great. At first, you'll probably think that this is another one of those cliche rom-com animes where the main character is going to take care the blonde girl because she's too dumb to take care of herself. I've seen these kind of animes before, to the point where it's just getting very annoying. You might also think that this is going to be a harem because Sorata lives in a dorm where the majority of the occupants are females. There's also the pointless fan-service, typical slice-of-life fooling around, Ecchi elements and many more cliches. At this point, I was ready to drop the show then the 2nd half came.


The second half of the series was awesome. If you were planning to drop the series because of how awful the first half is then don't. Just wait till the second half arrives and the wait will be all worth it. The second half is seperated into 3 plot points. 


The first is the love triangle between Sorata, Nanami, and Shiina and a love story between Misaki and Jin. In my opinion, the story was told perfectly and it further developed the main characters. It gets you thinking..who Sorata is going to be paired up with. Sorata looks up to Shiina because of how dedicated she is to her work. Shiina, at this point, probably started gaining feelings for Sorata but I'm not exactly sure. The way she's acting sometimes gets me confused as to whether or not she gained feelings for Sorata or she's just acting like that because she wants too. Nanami gained feelings for Sorata because she thinks she's a cool guy who picks up abandoned cats. This is why I liked the first plot point of the first half. They didn't just randomly gained feelings for that person. There was a relationship development. Now..the love story between Misaki and Jin. The love story here is bit complicated. It's not your usual "I love you, let's go out" love story. They eventually knew they had feelings for each other but Jin rejected her even though he loves her and he had his reasons. His reasons are very good and actually made sense. 


The second is the characters chasing their dreams/career. This is the BEST plot point out of the 3. Let me ask you a question..Have you ever experienced something in your life where you got rejected because there's that one person who is better than you? Have you ever experienced something in your life where you worked hard for years because you wanted that job/position but got rejected because there's that one person who is better than you? If you say yes then you will love how the show depicted the characters going through that stage. Yes, I've been there. That's why I knew what the characters were feeling,especially Nanami, where she worked hard for 2 years to pass the audition but failed. The world is unfair and we gotta learn how to live with it. 


The final plot point is the bond and feelings that they have gained for each other by living in Sakurasou. I found this  somewhat cheesy but it's still great to watch. This basically shows the strong bond that they have towards each other and will do everything to make sure it doesn't break. *hint the final 4 episodes will put them through that test hint* 


The pacing, in my opinion, is slow but I actually prefer slow story pacing. It means the show gets to further develop the characters and I get to know what's going on. The ending didn't felt rushed and it was a satisfying ending.

I watch anime to feel for the characters and to be moved by their struggles, failures and successes. If like me, you find enjoyment in being a part of a rom com, slice of life anime which can make you laugh, feel and cry then you should give Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo (Pet Girl of Sakurasou) a watch.
As a reviewer, I am biased by the fact that the first 2 anime I watched were Code Geass and Clannad/Clannad AS. Since then I've watched over 50 anime including the top 20 romance anime as listed on myanimelist. I tell you this, to help you todecide how I rate my anime, since such a process is as you'd expect a subjective opinion.


In terms of pure emotion or 'feels' my top 3 anime would be Clannad AS, Code Geass then Shigatsu wa Kimi no Uso. Sakurasou would still easily fit into the top 10 and particularly towards the end of the series, it becomes far more drama than comedy, as good shows do. I was spoilt in the sense of expecting all series to move me as much as my first 2 anime, but it is actually a huge struggle to find series that can touch and move you. I am pleased to say that this show can hold it's head high knowing that it has almost reached those heights of immersion and emotion.


So what makes this show special?


The story itself is based on the idea of an artistic genius who is however so gifted in art that she is unable to manage in any other sphere, be it, taking care of herself or understanding her emotions. She is thrown into the mix of sakurasou - which is a dorm for misfits who do not fit into the regular student dorms for whatever reason, whether it is because they keep pets (Sorata), too poor to afford it (Nanami), a geek shut in (Ryuunosoke), an anime genius (Misaki) and a playboy (Jin). Although it starts out with a bit too much fanservice for my liking, this quickly settles down as the story plays out and is not really a distraction later on.


The wide variety of character tropes means that there is something for everyone. At the heart of the show, there are 2 main themes - friendship and the balance between talent and hard work. One of the interesting things about the show is the focus on failure. Most shows just have characters succeeding at everything they try. Here we have characters experiencing defeat after defeat and we can watch them grow and mature as they deal with it. This opportunity to watch the characters grow and change is perhaps the best part of the series as there is nothing more annoying than characters who don't learn a thing over a series of 20+ episodes (one of the reasons I disliked My Teen Romantic Comedy SNAFU - which is also highly rated and may suit some).


The character designs are fabulous and the colours and artwork/animation is top notch, which is a given, since the genius in the show Mashiro is a painter. I also particularly enjoyed the soundtrack, including the openings and endings, which are mostly sung by the cast. Suffice to say that those 2 elements enhanced the experience and did not in any way distract from the show.


Summary:

A top grade rom com slice of life drama.

If you enjoyed, Clannad AS or am looking for an anime that can give you the 'feels'/emotional involvement - be sure to check this one out.

You will laugh, cry and grow to love the characters in this story. I know I did!

Pet Kanojo is an anime that focuseson a boy named Sorata Kanda and his trials in a dorm called Sakura-Sou, whether it be romantic, school, family, work, or just every problems. Sakura-Sou is a place where problem children from Suimei High reside, it has low rent and virtually no rules. Although, Sorata isn't a problem child, he just can't bear to lose his cat without giving it an owner. Thus, our story begins.


Now for you hardcore romance fans out there, like me, you are probably wondering, how far could the romance possibly progress in a setting such as this? And honestly, not as far as we would like, but that goes for many rom-com animes. But if you enjoy a good romance/comedy like I do, then you'll still enjoy this anime very much.


Now onto my specific review points.


Story 9/10

I really enjoy anime that have new and interesting story ideas, Pet Kanojo being one of them. It's not your typical romance, comedy, drama type anime, it has a lot more around it. It deals with large problems. Such as someone being so amazing at something they put everyone around them down. This story has much more than just that, but that is a big part of it. It also deals with romance, drama, and of course, hilarious comedy! There are little things in the background in some scenes you will have to rewind in order to make sure you saw it, they are absolutely hilarious.


Art 10/10

The art in this anime was fantastic. it was detailed, colorful, fluent, and symmetrical. The backgrounds had lots of detail and color, which is always nice to see. The characters were very well drawn and symmetrical, whether it be them talking, moving, or just their general art.


Sound 9/10

The sound in this anime was really nice as well. The voice actors all matched up to their characters nicely. Specially Mashiro's voice actor, that was a great match. All of the OP and ED songs were also very enjoyable. I actually found myself listening to the second ED song quite a bit, it was a catchy song :)


Character. 9/10

They did a very good job on portraying these characters. Also, they had a good background to each main character, which is always a treat. That allows you to really get sucked into this anime. I for one can't stand an anime with no background on characters or lacking background, I like to sympathize with the characters or sometimes even relate to them. So for the characters I think they did a very good job on allowing the audience to get to know them.


Enjoyment 10/10

I thoroughly enjoyed this anime, whether it be comedy, romance, or the SoL part. The comedy was absolutely amazing. The little things killed me, like hearing what someone said in the background or some random persons face during a scene. The romance did not progress as much as I wanted it to, but I can say that about most rom-com anime I have watched. It was also nice to see the little bit of SoL in it Them living their lives during their high school days and planning their future.

I've never written a review before and I'm not a very 'reviewy', critical person but here goes!
Sakurasou was one of my all time favourite animes. It is a rom-com, slice of life anime which focuses on the troubles, hardships, friendships and romance between students in an infamous dorm called Sakura Hall. 
At the start of the anime it seemed a bit odd, and the story progressed quite slowly. However it soon developed into a very complex story which drew me in. It focused on different characters, how they perceived their lives and how they fought towards what they wanted in life. It was different toother rom-coms I have seen in that it didn't just focus on romance and heartbreak, but intertwined this with the characters desire to achieve their goals and dreams which often led to them falling short of these dreams. However the characters kept pursuing said dreams. It focused mainly on the main character Sorata who was an average student pursuing a career in game design. He was a character who was very easy to relate to, as I'm sure many people see themselves in the struggles he went through trying to do what he loved whilst comparing himself to those around him. All in all the story line was complex, deeply moving and often saddening, however it was filled with hilarious moments. \n
The art was beautiful. The soundtrack was also beautiful and complemented everything well. The story was complex and had many good life lessons such as learning to cope with hardships, falling short of your dreams and pursuing what you love no matter what. The characters (apart from Mashiro she was pretty bland sorry, but still an interesting character) were complex, yet had that element of comedy in them all also. \n\n
All in all it was a brilliant anime and was by far a favourite of mine. I would recommend it to anyone who is looking for a comedic, romancey, yet complex story full of extremely emotional moments.

Summary: If you're into slice of life comedy/romance anime, you're sure in for a treat! This might be the best slice of life anime I've ever seen. The art is beautiful, the characters are absolutely wonderful and fully developed, the story is fairly simple and straight forward, taking a few dark turns just long enough to explore a few interesting concepts but still keep the mood light. It has comedy, romance, sadness and tons of character developments. Plus it has a satisfying and complete ending that doesn't feel rushed or leave me wanting more (in a bad way). If you're into high school slice oflife anime this will likely be a winner for you!

It is facing the hard truth that some people are just born naturally amazing and gifted and that all the hard work in the world can't always make up for that fact. Granted, this isn't the main arc of the story and doesn't derail the feels, but it is definitely a darker theme for a slice of life and added a new angle I found fascinating. Also, the anime ends in a perfect place after they took the time to flesh out the ending and I wasn't left wanting more.


Sidebar: I didn't completely love the romance arcs and the direction the authors took it, but it wasn't bad just a personal preference.

*Warning may contain spoilers*
So based on the synopsis, Sakurasou is a rom-com, high school slice of life anime - a genre that is pretty standard and generic, and one which I tend to avoid. As I was just looking for something light and easy to watch to pass time, I didn't have alot of expectations going into the show. However, by the end I was left pretty dumbstruck by what I've just watched. Sakurasou is really a case of "dont judge a book by its cover", it will definitely take you by surprise.
STORY: 8
The story in Sakurasou starts off fairly slow and generic, our mainprotagonist Sorata moves into a dorm full of problematic students, or the misfits of the school. He is initially set on moving out at the first opportunity, however as the story progresses we find that he eventually becomes attached to Sakurasou and its eccentric residents. However, the other much more interesting aspect of the story is on the ambitions and dreams of each character in the story, and how they struggle to achieve their own goals. Personally, this is a concept that's very relatable to me at different stages in life - whether its studying for grades, college applications or career aspirations. The show really manages to highlight the realities of life, where we're often met with failures before we find success, do we simply give up? or pick up the pieces and start again. The plot also plays around with the idea of people who are naturally talented vs those who have to try - and again this is a very interesting concept which adds alot of depth to the story of the anime. A number of reviews have commented on the (lack of) romance between the main characters, and I agree that this hasn't been very well executed. However, personally I didn't find that the romance was a very important element to the plot in Sakurasou and so I didn't really have any problems with it. 


ART: 9

The art is another very strong aspect of Sakurasou. The anime is beautifully animated and utilisese a very bright palette of colours which I find very pleasing to watch. Most scenes, particularly the important scenes were very well executed and its evident that alot of attention was given to very small details. The character designs are also very well done.


SOUND: 8

The sound is generally well done, and both the OP/ED are good and complements the overall theme and genre of the anime.  


CHARACTERS: 10

This is easily one of the most important aspect of Sakurasou, and what really sets it apart from the cliches that we find in other similar high school animes. The thing is, Sakurasou's characters are not particularly unique, in fact many of them can easily fall into the generic stereotypes that we find in many animes. However, each character was so well executed that together they really created a dynamic that was very unique to Sakurasou. In my opinion all the characters were pivotal to the main plot, and none of them really felt like extras to the show. All of the characters were very well developed, with their own unique backstories. Because of this I was able to connect deeply with the characters. I was able to relate to their motivations, and understand why they reacted in a certain way to various events. At times Sakurasou was also an emotional roller coaster. I experienced different emotions together with the characters as events in the anime unfold - happiness as they celebrated their success or sadness and anger when they were met with failure. 


ENJOYMENT: 10

Sakurasou was a very enjoyable anime, one which I think many viewers can truly relate to. It successfully manages to play around with a seemingly generic high school setting to create a very enjoyable anime. An interesting and surprisingly deep story, an eccentric array of well developed characters which together create a very unique atmosphere for the show.


To sum up, Sakurasou is definitely a must watch for any slice of life and rom-com fans, but also for other viewers because its very unique and different from the cliches that are common in this genre.
